unit_learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate critical understanding of the concepts of intelligence.
Critically analyse a case study, demonstrating professional judgment and assessment.
Demonstrate the ability to evaluate, select and synthesise knowledge from different sources.
Evaluate how the intelligence function fits within the dynamic national security context.
Demonstrate higher order communication skills including the ability to formulate sustained, persuasive and original written and oral arguments.

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Students prepare for classes each week by completing the required readings and analysing the key questions for each seminar topic

assessments.description: By the end of the unit, students will have a better understanding of the relationship between intelligence and policy. To demonstrate this knowledge, students will write an intelligence report, ostensibly to an appropriate policymaker, about a current intelligence issue.
Internal students will demonstrate active engagement in seminars; external students will demonstrate it by contributing to online activities.

Students will explore the analytical themes of the course through the lens of a specific intelligence/policy case. Students are free to choose any relevant case from any time period, provided it is reasonably well-documented.
Students will be asked to complete essays on a range of topics, requiring students to employ materials from the classroom discussions as well as the assigned readings.

academic_org.value: Department of Security Studies and Criminology

data.description: This unit exposes students to the diverse areas of intelligence and to intelligence process methodologies in a variety of contexts. It discusses the essential characteristics of intelligence systems and examines how the intelligence function fits within a dynamic national security context, situating the intelligence function within the Law Enforcement, Foreign, National Security and Military domains. The unit examines the Australian and selected international intelligence communities. All enrolment queries should be directed to Open Universities Australia (OUA): see www.open.edu.au
